content.description: Climbs the featured prow up the left hand side of the crag. As of May 2019, it is the farthest left hand bolt line on this wall.
content.location: Hike up about 15' off of the main trail and start behind a small tree.

content.description: One of the nicer moderates at Allenspur. A little bit of everything on this one. Start either directly on the face or in a small dihedral feature. First ascends a steepish face using flakes and edges to gain a large slabby ledge at 1/2-height underneath a small roof. Commit to the roof pull (super fun!) and continue up on more juggy face/slab to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts (7) to hooks with a backup bolt.
content.location: Farthest right bolted route on the crag up the gray rock. Distinguished by the small roof feature about halfway up.

content.description: A varied route with a crux up high on technical terrain involving good holds with poor feet. Shares a couple holds with OTW, but climbs superbly!
content.location: Starts just right of Deforestation in the offwidth crack.

content.description: Climb easy slab to a roof.  Pull the roof and fire up the left leaning seam to a ledge.  Some thoughtful slab moves lead to chains.
content.location: Right of Crack to Nowhere.  There are two bolt lines after the roof, take the left line toward the dead tree protruding from atop the cliff.

content.description:
Stick clip the first bolt and climb ten feet of thin hands/layback crack till it peters out to the crux. Reach straight up, crimp hard on some very small holds and snag the jug flake to clip. From there, start the traverse right on your choice of small pockets and crimps or the sloping rail above. The climbing eases to 5.8 once you reach the "pillar". Stay mostly on the face and stem the right-hand wall to the top. Enjoy the view!

This climb is technical and demands an attentive belay, due to it's traversing nature.
content.protection:
7 bolts to chain anchor.

Stick-clip the first bolt.

Have the second person top rope to clean.
content.location: Farthest possible route on climber's right of Obscurity Crag. Walk 20 feet past Reindeer Games (5.10a) and scramble up to a convenient belay. South facing.

content.description: An easy slab leads straight up through a mini roof to a balancy stance on the lip. Reach up to the jug rail on the headwall and clip a bolt. Traverse right across the lip which leads to the arete. Head back left using the crack, with clipping jug up right of the chains. This route wanders and is full of tech, but is quite fun once you know where to go.
content.location: Gray slab to white pillar, just right of Unfilled Dreams.

content.description: This line tackles the golden face to the left of Unfilled Dreams.  Scramble the first 15 feet up easy slab and ledges to the first bolt. Delicate stemming and laybacking through interesting holds leads to an obvious traverse left to the high gray corner. Powerful laybacks lead to the anchors.
content.protection: 6-7 bolts to fixed anchors.  Can be top roped from the anchors of Unfilled Dreams.
content.location: Continue right past 7-11 Crag on good trails to Obscurity Crag.  Out of the Whole is the second to last line, and shares anchors with Unfilled dreams.

content.description: Easy slab cracks lead to a classic stem corner with killer hand jams. Lots of variety on this one, and worth bringing a few pieces for!
content.location: Same start as Out of the Hole, head left up the obvious corner.

content.description: Slabs to headwall. We bolted it and climbed it immediately afterwards.
content.location: This climb is between two climbs, at least one being a trad climb (Wind ranger and crack to nowhere? I aplogize but I just dont remember) that have their own anchors. Im not sure that the trad lines are recorded here on MP. The trad climb to the right is easy, low angle with huge cracks to an old school style chain anchor.

content.description: Starts on a steep bright colored face with an amazing heel hook clip with some cruxy moves getting up into a decent rest.
content.location: Down a bit and to the left of Out of the Whole, starts on a face with the heel hook side pull feature, but eventually tops out onto rest and working up the entire arete to the left of out of the whole

content.description:
Great route on good rock following a left-trending finger crack/flake down low, and then up into a series of cracks in a ill-defined dihedral. Definite crux down low traversing the crack leftward to gain good jugs, as the feet dwindle. Stiff for the grade.

Apparently used to be a gear climb, until bolts were placed. Bonus points for not clipping bolts!

A little bit of loose rock in the final fist crack, so be wary.
content.protection: Gear to 3", or clip the nice shiny (and welcome) 7 bolts. Two open-cold shuts with a bolt backup for the anchor.
content.location: Obvious left-arching bolted crack on the left side of the main bolted part of the crag. Look for the huge dead tree snagged at the clifftop. This route starts on a small pedestal and ends to the left of the tree.
